chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Public trust rises when institutions make it easy for people to see what was decided, who benefits, what it costs, and how success will be measured—then publish results regularly and correct course when goals aren’t met. Create clear, safe ways to report problems and wrongdoing, with real consequences enforced by independent bodies, while protecting privacy and due process. Pair this with ongoing, neighborhood-level co-design and oversight so residents can help set priorities and verify that services are improving in ways they can actually experience.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: To rebuild public trust, institutions should make decisions transparently—using plain, multilingual explanations of goals, evidence, and trade-offs—and publish accessible data so people can verify results. Trust grows when accountability is real and independent (audits, oversight, and fair consequences), paired with humility: admitting mistakes, fixing them quickly, and showing what changed. Consistent, reliable delivery of everyday services, combined with meaningful local participation and civic education, helps communities see institutions as competent, fair, and responsive rather than distant or partisan.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Public trust increases when institutions are consistently transparent about how decisions are made, publish clear and multilingual explanations of evidence and trade-offs, and make budgets and performance data easy to verify. It also requires independent audits, fair and enforceable consequences for wrongdoing, and rapid, visible fixes when services fail. Create ongoing local oversight and participation—especially for marginalized communities—so people can help shape priorities and see results in everyday life while protecting privacy and due process.
